comments.text:
+Ismael Cisneros Hernandez
So? In the italian movies may be lawful to translate in italian the songs 
of Iglesias, Ricky Martin, Shakira or the english or french songs? There is 
nothing of bad in the choice of the director, but your argoument is 
meanngless. I hate that in Italy the big majority of the movies are dubbed, 
but I don't think it's the same thing of a song.
comments.author: S Venezia

comments.text:
I believe that they (the director and producers) chose the Spanish version 
of the song (called 'No soy una señora' and performed by María José), 
because (and I'll be sinning of obvious) the movie language is Spanish.
comments.author: Ismael Cisneros Hernandez

comments.text: Es una hermosa historia.... Simple pero con un gran sentido de la vida... ﻿
comments.author: Vlogyago D

comments.text: Blue and Not so Pink. :3﻿
comments.author: Domenique Milaño

comments.text:
as a venezuelan gay guy myself i never thought i'd see the day a movie 
from my country were to be released by Tlareleasing ,  i'd been a huge 
follower for years, makes me proud and hopeful! but "my straight son"? did 
the person who picked the title actually watch the movie? it has absolutely 
nothing to do with the son's sexuality! he is in fact the more sexually 
comfortable of all the characters which makes the title twice as wrong! 
 the original title was perfect, "blue , not so pink".  not a big fan of 
the movie tho, big performances from experienced actors in national tv 
which had a big impact on the cinemas, cuz people is not used to watch soap 
opera macho type actors in these kind of roles in latin america but the 
movie itself it's a succession of bad cliches.. not offensive,, fairly 
enjoyable with endearing characters but not representative of the lgtb 
community at all.﻿

comments.text: Really good. A bit sad but good.﻿

the context because we don't use them.
It looks like a great movie.

comments.text: It's not "pal", it's "pana"...﻿
comments.author: Germán Rivas

comments.text:
Have you seen the movie? He calls everyone "Pal", which is why the son got 
mad and told him not to call him that anymore, because he is not his "Pal" 
or "friend", he is his son. Also, when localizing a movie, some changes 
have to be made so that the target audience can understand the context of 
the conversation.
comments.author: lpblitz

comments.text: +Germán Rivas
comments.author: Hazahar Idris

comments.text:
I mean that it's not a nice expression for a loved one, you can say, for 
example: ¡Pana! ¿Qué te pasa?  and it's like an exclamation. it's like an 
onomatopoeia, just an expression
comments.author: Germán Rivas

comments.text:
but it isn't a translation properly, in Venezuela it's like a pronoun, 
something like dude or like in Spain the people says "tío"
comments.author: Germán Rivas

comments.text:
pal is a translation for Pana
 Pal,Homie, Buddy, Mate are informal ways to say Friend
